moves.1. d4: A simple game in whcih white lost a piece early, and black then played it out without giving white any chances of receovery.
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. a3 Bxc3+:
I was waiting for this move so I can play with my favortie b6.
That is no use earlier because then white has the counter f2-f3, building a strong center.
moves.7... b6 8. e3 Bb7:
Black has gained control over the white squares, but white has a strong center still.
It needs to be undermined, preferably with d6 and e5.
moves.9. g3:
Bd3 would have been consistent, white should have concentrated on a quick development.
This creates weaknesses on the white fields surrounding the future home of whites king.
moves.9... d6 10. Bg2 Nbd7: Preparing for the break e6-e5, after which balck has a slightly better position.
moves.11. O-O Qc7:
In this position theknight is worth more then the bisshop, so white shold have taken the knight with Bxf6.
The knight is about to move to a strong placve in the cnter, and the bisshop has little room to manoever.
Had white not played g2-g3, the bisshop could have gone to g3, where it wold have been been placed good, aiming blacks Queen.
This costs a piece, correct would have been 14.Bxb7, Qxb7; 16.Bxg5
Then black can counter h6 with Be7, because the pawn d6 has no cover.
moves.15... Bxg2 16. Kxg2 h6:
Now be7 is no use because of Re8 or Rf7.
White loese the bisshop wherever it goes.
moves.17. Bf4 e5 18. Bxh6 gxh6 19. Qe2 Nf6: Taking aim at whites king already
moves.20. Rad1 cxd4: Exposing the weak pawn at c4, and opening the important c file for blacks rooks
moves.21. cxd4 Rac8 22. Qd3 Ne4 23. Rdc1 Qb7: Taing the Queen out of sight of that white rook, and creating some dangerous tactical tricks by aiming whites kingside
moves.24. Kg1 Ng5: Theatens Kh3 already. White has to act to protect his king
moves.25. d5 e4: Taing hold of that the filed f3 for his Night. Blacks Queen will soon follow via b7-f7-h5
moves.26. Qc3 Nf3+ 27. Kg2 Qf7 28. Qc2: Reinformcement on the King side are required uregntly, so white Queen moves to e2
moves.28... Qh5 29. Rfh1 Ne5 30. Qd1 Qxd1: Of course, the endgame is an easy win.
moves.31. Rhxd1 Rc5 32. h3 Rfc8 33. Rd2 Kf7:
The is no hurry. Balck moves his king to d7 to be able protect the c-file.
White is not only a piece down, he can only wiat while black prepares to finish him of
moves.34. Rcc2 Ke7 35. a4 Rc5xc4:
The a4 pawn is on black menu too.
After that the plan is a simple advance of the b and a pawn supported by both rooks and the knight.
Note waht a strong position the knight has on e5.
moves.36. Rca2 Rc8c5 37. h4 Ra5 38. Kf1 Raxa4: Bad move, and one whcih leads to a quick checkmate
moves.41... Nf3:
White surrendered. he can give a few check on the balck king, but the he has nothing to prevent checkmate with Re1#

All in all a simple game where balck gained a piece earl, and then played it out with some precise play.
